I think right now @Frame_io is by far the best UX for this, but it's not quite there -- needs a different part of the product oriented towards a community watching & discussing together, not just focused on video production review.

Bonus features:
- High quality social UX (emoji reactions, well designed comments, prioritize conversation)
- Remixing
- Slack integration
- Github + Twitter OAuth

Key Features: 
- AMAZING UX (>= YouTube or Frame)
- threaded comments
- comments anchored by time
- High quality video (1080p+)
- Speed-up playback (1.5x, 2x, 2.5x)
- Group ACLs (GApp OAuth a plus)
- Passworded links
- Video Playlists
- Group & personalized Video Feeds

Ask Twitter: what's the best *private* group video platform? Looking for something as high quality as @Frame_io but tuned for publishing, sharing, commenting, discussing in large *private* groups (100s, 1,000s).

@eordano @KyleSamani @zkCapital That does not describe most P2P or decentralized nets today (most cannot operate in partition). \n\nI‚Äôve been resurfacing Paul‚Äôs reasoning, his arguments for achieving near perfect resilience, and the importance of not relying on a special subset of nodes, by using his definitions.

@eordano @KyleSamani @zkCapital Key reason I use Paul‚Äôs original definition is to recall a crucial point people often miss today: resilient networks should be a uniform mesh ‚Äî all nodes running the same protocol/role, capable of providing same service (eg routing), & partitions continue to operate locally

@eordano @KyleSamani @zkCapital People have used the phrase ‚Äúdistributed network‚Äù in drastically broader (even meaningless) terms since. Language evolves. But that doesn‚Äôt make the original definition a misconception :)

@eordano @KyleSamani @zkCapital It‚Äôs coming from the original definition. Read https://t.co/xNHCoDqE3R ‚Äî Paul Baran invented packet switching and distributed networks, and started the field through a series of RAND research memos.

Until this happens, great promise of financial innovation blockchains bring is limited to v high value txns or devs. No broad consumers.
We need agreement and buy in from the major players to drastically improve UX industry wide (across orgs and systems), no factions.
It HAS to get easier for apps to build on common standards for all this, across all wallets, exchanges, custodians, clients... Standards!!
It HAS to get easy to verify correct identity to given keys (or HD root keys, or multisigs) on all major wallets (browser certs, twitter).
It HAS to get easy to add multiple key custodians to multisig constructions on all major wallets/custodians/exchanges (custodian standard?)
It HAS to get easy to send aux data via QR code & copy-paste (Bitcoin, doable w multiple outputs, Ethereum w data field) on major wallets.
It HAS to get easy to get trivially easy to do HDM (or equivalent) on both Bitcoin and Ethereum, on all major wallets.
It HAS to get easy to verify HD wallet child keys stem from the right root on all major wallets. (Standard)
It HAS to get easy to do payments on all major wallets to multiple outputs (btc), or contracts w data (eth) from QR codes & copy-paste.
UX for doing interesting payments with both Bitcoin and Ethereum is really terrible. Another reason they haven't started to replace much.

@bitemyapp @kiarafrobles The whole internet owned, and you know it. Better certs here help, but not much. Stop being a jerk, and start helping to fix the problems.
@bitemyapp @kiarafrobles But if you think us having slightly better certs is a Night/Day difference and that solves the problem 80/90%, then you're totally deluded.
@bitemyapp @kiarafrobles If your point is "hey, do better", then: agreed, you're right, we're on it now.
@bitemyapp @kiarafrobles For now, but not in long term. Trust & Bootstrap is a problem at every level. Can do better today with PKs & certs in consensus protocols
@bitemyapp @kiarafrobles You are speaking as if trusting root CAs is the only option, and it's not. Better models are coming, and fast.
@bitemyapp @kiarafrobles But to be perfectly clear, long term we WON'T be relying on CAs like this. Today's CAs model is not the best nor only model. (6)
@bitemyapp @kiarafrobles And today, we unfortunately DO rely on both DNS and CAs, so we should have the best options possible there. FYI, we ARE switching certs. (5)
@bitemyapp @kiarafrobles But you're totally right that IF we have some infra, it should be as secure as we can possibly make it. (This takes time. Help us out) (4)
@bitemyapp @kiarafrobles _Relying_ on CAs/TLS or DNS is not a good idea long term. We're working towards a content model with stronger guarantees. (3)
@bitemyapp @kiarafrobles The point is to move the content such that blocking or failure in DNS and CAs cannot prevent the distribution of content (2)
@bitemyapp @kiarafrobles We're not intervening. We're providing hash-linked distributed content. Our gateway is not the point here, TLS is not the point. (1)
